citation.article-title: A new obligate halophilic methane-producing bacterium.

p.s: Description of Methanococcus halophilus sp. nov.
Methanococcus halophilus (salt-loving methanococcus)
Morphology: irregular polygonal cocci, 0.5-2 μm in diameter.
Cocci singly or in pairs. tend to aggregate through slime.
Multiply by constriction of cell in half, and not by fission.
Cocci do not have flagella, and are surrounded by slime.
Sensitive to 0.07% Sarcosyl Nl-30.
Cell wall osmotically unstable, lysed in hypertonic solutions.
Colonies: not formed on agar in pure culture.
Growth in liquid medium: disperse growth with increase in medium turbidity.
Response to temperature: growth optimum 26-36°C.
No growth above 45°C.
Good growth at 18°C.
Response to pH: growth optimum in range pH 6.5-1.4 with maximum at pH 1.4.
No growth above pH 8.0 or below pH 6.3.
Physiology: strict anaerobe.
Methylamines and methanol used as substrates for growth and methane production.
H2 + CO2, formate, and acetate not utilized.
Nutrition: obligate moderate halophile.
Growth optimum at 7-9% NaCl.
Good groth at 15% NaCl.
No growth at 1.5% or lower.
Does not require yeast extract and other organic growth factors.
Yeast extract and trypticase inhibit growth at a concentration of 0.05%.
Source: cyanobacterial mat with mud deposit from Hamelin Pool.
Shark Bay. northwestern Australia.
Type strain: Z-7982 deposited at the Institute of Microbiology, Academy of Sciences of the USSR.
After this paper was submitted for publication. we discovered that organisms with similar characters were isolated under the name Methanolobua tindarius (König and Stetter. 1982.
German Section of the ASM, kv13) and Methanocoides methylutens (Sowers and Ferry, 1983.
Appl.
Environ.
Microbiol.).
Stain Z-7982 belongs in this group distinguished by its halophilic nature. and is thus at least an independent species of one of these newly created genera.
